title: Car Colston Walk Route

images.title: Cattle grazing on Large Green, Car Colston by Alan Murray-Rust, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cattle grazing on Large Green, Car Colston. In 1598 landowners had fields within the parish enclosed, but agreed on leaving the greens open so that cottagers could graze their cattle, geese and horses.

images.title: The Royal Oak, Car Colston by Richard Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Royal Oak, Car Colston

images.title: Footbridge over drainage channel, Large Green by Richard Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footbridge over drainage channel, Large Green

images.title: Richard Croft / Little Green
images.caption: Little Green. The smaller of the two greens in the village.

images.title: Richard Croft / Brunsell Hall
images.caption: Brunsell Hall. The remaining part of a much larger house built in 1662 by Dr Samuel Brunsell, rector of Bingham and Screveton. Most of the house was pulled down in 1759

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Hawksworth Road, Screveton
images.caption: Hawksworth Road, Screveton. The large white house is Beans Farmhouse. It is no longer a farm, with the outbuildings now all converted for residential use.

images.title: Richard Croft / St.Wilfred's church
images.caption: St.Wilfred's church. Largely medieval church located west of the village of Screveton

images.title: Richard Croft / St.Mary's church
images.caption: View to St.Mary's church from Car Lane, Car Colston

description: This Nottinghamshire based village is located in the Rushcliffe borough of the county. The pretty village is noted for its two large Elizabethan greens, the larger of which is thought to be the biggest green in England. It's an historic and interesting place for a stroll with several 18th and early 19th century buildings, many of which are listed. This circular walk in the village takes you across the greens to the neighbouring village of Screveton. Here you could pay a visit to the Grade I listed St Wilfrid's Church which dates to the 13th century. To continue your walking in the Car Colston head a short distance west to visit nearby Gunthorpe where you can enjoy a riverside walk along the River Trent Valley Way .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Head to the Royal Oak for some refreshment after your exercise. The 200 yeard old pub sits in a fine location next to the large village green. You can sit outside and enjoy a drink with a view over the green and the village. The pub can be found at postcode NG13 8JE for your sat navs. Theere is car parking available and they are also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the south there's the town of Bingham where you can try the Bingham Linear Walk. The pleasant route runs along a disused railway line through the town and then out into the countryside where there are views of the River Smite.

display_address: Screveton Road, Car Colston, Scarrington, Rushcliffe, Nottinghamshire, East Midlands, England, NG13 8JF, United Kingdom
